clean_story:
Faraway worlds. Light as a messenger.

"Exoplanet" means a planet outside our solar system—exo for "outside," planet for the world itself.

They’re too distant to visit, so scientists study their light.
When a planet passes in front of its star, it dims the starlight slightly—like a moth flying past a lamp.
Telescopes like Kepler and James Webb measure this flicker to reveal the planet’s size, orbit, even hints of its atmosphere.
Some exoplanets are scorching gas giants; others might hold water.
In 2017, TRAPPIST-1 made headlines: seven Earth-sized planets orbiting one star, three in the "habitable zone" where liquid water could exist.
But "could" isn’t "does. "
Light takes years to reach us—so we’re studying planets as they were decades or centuries ago.
The real question isn’t just where they are, but when we’re seeing them.
Atmospheric chemistry.
The search for biosignatures.
Time as a telescope.
